revision.comment: /* References */ [[Category:Royal Air Force pilots of World War II]]
revision.text:
'''Alois Vašátko''' [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]] [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|DFC]] (25 August 1908, [[Čelákovice]], [[Czechoslovakia]] – 23 June 1942)<ref>{{cite book |title=Mnozí nedoletěli |last=Loucký |first=František |authorlink= |year=1989 |publisher=Naše vojsko |location=Praha |isbn=80-206-0053-1 |page=226}}</ref> was a Czech fighter pilot. Together with [[Josef František]] and [[Karel Kuttelwascher]] Vašátko is one of the most successful Czech fighter pilots.
Vašátko was born in Čelákovice on 25 August 1908. After graduating from a teachers' institute, he became a teacher in [[Litoměřice]]. A couple of months later he was drafted into the army. He finished his military service in 1929 and started studies at several army institutes. During 1937 he attended pilot training in [[Olomouc]], and by September 1938 he was commanding officer of ''Letka C.14'', equipped with the [[Letov Š-28|Letov Š-328]] biplane.<ref>Shores/Williams ; 'Aces High'(1994) ; page 605.</ref>
Following the first dissolution of Czechoslovakia and the annexation of Bohemia and Moravia by [[Nazi Germany]], he fled the country. He travelled to France via Poland and after re-training at a fighter school at [[Chartres]] he joined ''Groupe de Chasse'' I/5. Flying a [[Curtiss P-36 Hawk|Curtiss 75]], he shot down 3 aircraft solo, shared in 9 group kills and shared in two 'probables'. He became the most successful Czechoslovak fighter pilot in the [[Battle of France]].
[[File:Air Ministry Second World War Official Collection CH1434.jpg|thumb|right|<center>Armourers preparing ammunition belts, with Hurricane DU-J in which Vašátko helped shoot down a Junkers Ju 88 on 8 October 1940 in the background</center>]] After the retreat from France Vašátko took part in the [[Battle of Britain]]. As an RAF Pilot Officer he joined [[No. 312 Squadron RAF|No. 312 (Czechoslovak) Squadron]] and, together with S/L Denys Gillam and Sgt. Josef Stehlík, scored its first victory, when they downed a [[Junkers Ju 88]] of ''Kampfgruppe 806'' above [[Liverpool]] on 8 October 1940.<ref>[http://www.south-lancs-aviation.bravepages.com/ju88.htm Shooting down of a Ju88 by No 312 Squadron<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>Václav Kolesa, ''Duel in the sky III.'', Zlínek 3/1991, page 16-17, includes camouflages of Hurricane L1926/DU-J flown by Alois Vašátko and shot-down Junkers 4068/M7+DK</ref>
On 5 June 1941 he was promoted to Squadron Leader and on 30 May 1942 he became Wing Commander of the newly created Czechoslovak Fighter Wing. He was killed in action on 23 June 1942, when he crashed into the sea after a dogfight with [[Focke-Wulf Fw 190]]s, colliding with the aircraft of ''Unteroffizier'' Wilhelm Reuschling from 7 ''staffel'', [[Jagdgeschwader 2]]. Having no known grave, he is commemorated on the [[Air Forces Memorial|Runnymede Memorial]] by the [[Commonwealth War Graves Commission]].<ref>[http://cwgc.org.uk/find-war-dead/1809280/VASATKO,%20ALOIS] CWGC Casualty Record.</ref>
Vašátko's full wartime record was 4 solo and 10 shared aircraft destroyed, 2 (and 2 shared) probables, and 1 damaged.<ref>Shores/Williams ; 'Aces High'(1994) ; page 605.</ref>
He had been awarded many Czechoslovak and Allied orders and medals, including French Legion d’honneur – Chevalier, Croix de Guerre with seven palms, two golden stars and one silver star and the British Distinguished Flying Cross (D.F.C.), which he received on the day of his death.
He married Junette Ferdinando.
